did.unittitle: First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Detroit Records 1845-2012
did.abstract: The First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Detroit Records comprise over 150 years of records documenting the activities of the church's ministers, administrative bodies, committees and interest groups, and members. The first such denomination in the Detroit area, First U-U traces its history to the mid-nineteenth century and represents the convergence of two like-minded denominations founded on principles of humanism, social consciousness, and civic responsibility. The collection's five series contain materials pertaining to the church's history and development, administration, religious services, educational programs, and community engagement.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were donated by The First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Detroit (Donor No. 10908) in 2013.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Detroit Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Detroit was formed with the merger of two local denominations with a common mission of social progressivism and skepticism towards religious dogma. The church's early history may be traced to the First Congregational Unitarian Society of Detroit, which was founded in 1850 and known then as the Railroad Church due to its membership being comprised largely of railroad workers. Local Universalist and Unitarian congregations were officially incorporated as churches in 1880 and 1890, respectively. The present church building was erected in 1916 as the First Universalist Church (Church of Our Father). Following a successful temporary union in 1932, a binding legal agreement joined the Unitarian and Universalist congregations permanently, thus forming the Unitarian-Universalist Church of Our Father in 1934. In 1960, the church's name was officially changed to the First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Detroit, one year before the two denominations consolidated on the national level to form the Unitarian Universalist Association (UUA).

The church's long history of social justice work began in the 1850s when Unitarian Reverend Thomas J. Mumford expressed public opposition to capital punishment and the Fugitive Slave Act. Church activities and civic engagement efforts have long been guided by its foundational principles, which include freedom of thought, the importance of individual spiritual and intellectual development, service to the community, and inclusivity. First U-U maintains group memberships in the ACLU, NAACP, and Planned Parenthood. Its current mission is to serve as an urban center for spiritual renewal and social justice in Detroit, in addition to continuing its worship and religious education initiatives.

scopecontent.p: The First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Detroit Records comprise the collected documentation of the activities of the church's administrative bodies, committees, and congregation members. The collection contains materials pertaining to the church's history and development, governance, and religious, educational, and community service activities. The collection is divided into five series: Ministry and Membership, Church Administration, Church Committees and Organizations, Church Activities, and Newsletters and Orders of Service.

The Ministry and Membership series (2.5 linear feet) is divided into two subseries (Ministers and Membership). The former subseries is composed of minister's sermons, correspondence, photographs, and documents pertaining to ministerial searches. The records of ministers Rudolf C. (Rudi) Gelsey, Larry G. Hutchinson, Tracy Pullman, and Augustus P. Reccord are particularly well-represented. The latter subseries contains membership directories, records of birth, death, and marriage, photographs, and press clippings pertaining to particular church members.

did.unittitle: Assorted ministers (Mumford, Reccord, Stuart, Pullman), photographs 1852, 1900 undated
Pastor's wedding and funeral record book 1970-1974
Anne Pawlik (winning City Council award) undated
Judge Wade McCree memorial service undated
Press clippings pertaining to particular members 1960s-1990s

scopecontent.p: The Church Administration series (6.3 linear feet) is divided into seven subseries: Administrative Records, Board of Directors, Church Council, Church Trust, Congregational Meetings, Church History, and The Unitarian-Universalist Church at the National Level.

The first subseries contains records pertaining to church administration at the highest level, which include church constitutions and bylaws, mortgages and other property records, financial records, and administrative correspondence.

did.unittitle: Treasurer's reports and other financial documents
Staff lists and organizational charts 1960s, 1980s undated

scopecontent.p: The second subseries contains the records of the church's governing body, which has been known alternately as the Board of Directors, Board of Trustees, and the Governing Board. This subseries predominantly consists of meeting minutes, reports to the Board, policy documents, and correspondence.
The third subseries contains meeting minutes and annual reports of the Church Council.
The fourth subseries consists of Church Trust meeting minutes, declarations of trust, assorted financial records, and correspondence.
The fifth subseries contains minutes, reports, and other documentation of the proceedings of annual congregational meetings.

The sixth subseries contains some of the earliest extant documentation of the church, including the founding documents and records of the First Congregational Unitarian Society of Detroit, and other materials related to the church's formation. This subseries also contains historical overviews and records pertaining to the history of church buildings and property, including the McAdow House and Ernest M. Skinner Organ.

did.unittitle: First Congregational Unitarian Society of Detroit
Merger of the First Congregational Unitarian Society of Detroit and the First Universalist Church of Detroit
Archives of the First Unitarian-Universalist Church, correspondence 1990
Resources for preserving congregational archives undated
State Registry of Historic Sites, correspondence 1976-1977
Stained glass windows, records and correspondence 1950s, 1991
The Unitarian-Universalist Church at the National Level

scopecontent.p: The seventh and last subseries concerns the Unitarian-Universalist Church as a national organization, and contains records of the national Unitarian-Universalist merger, conference photographs, and assorted records from other Unitarian-Universalist churches, mainly in Michigan.

did.unittitle: Report of the coordinating committee on consolidation 1961
Lake Geneva Unitarian Summer Assembly, photographs 1941, 1942
Birmingham Unitarian Church (Bloomfield Hills, MI), records 1957-1959
Unitarian-Universalist Church of East Liberty (Clark Lake, MI)
First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Lyons, OH, orders of service 1980s
Community Church of New York, newsletters 1981-1987
Assorted Unitarian-Universalist churches, sermons and essays 1980s-1990s
Assorted Unitarian-Universalist churches, pamphlets and orders of service 1928, 1950s-1980s

scopecontent.p: The Church Committees and Organizations series (4.2 linear feet) is composed of materials related to the activities of the church's numerous committees, clubs, and interest groups. It is divided into four subseries: Committees, Church Clubs, Women's Alliance (National Alliance of Unitarian and Other Liberal Christian Women), and Other Women's Groups.

The first subseries consists of minutes, reports, and events programming for twelve committees organized around church management, ministry, and community service. Records of the Worship Committee, which is responsible for planning worship services, church activities, and attending to the needs of the congregation, comprise the bulk of this subseries.

did.unittitle: "An interpathic interpretation of African-American male alienation from the church," by Darryl W. Robinson 2000
Birmingham Unitarian Church/First U-U Church of Detroit Coalition, minutes and activities 1999, 2000
Leading congregations in worship: a guide 1983
Assorted reference materials for worship leaders undated

scopecontent.p: The second subseries consists of minutes, reports, correspondence, membership rosters, and events programming for 17 clubs organized around various constituencies (youth and students, women) and around artistic, cultural, and community service pursuits.

did.unittitle: Busy Bee Serving Society, membership directory undated
Channing Club and College Club assorted records 1940s-1950s
Multiple Arts Club, minutes and events 1957-1959
Women's Alliance (National Alliance of Unitarian and Other Liberal Christian Women)

scopecontent.p: The third subseries contains administrative records, annual programs, member directories, minutes, reports, and subcommittee records for one of the church's most prominent women's groups.

The fourth subseries contains administrative records, minutes, and correspondence from other national and Michigan-based women's groups, including the Ladies Union of the First Universalist Church of Detroit and the Clara Barton Sisterhood.

did.unittitle: Ladies Union of the First Universalist Church of Detroit
"In sisterhood...the life stories of the Unitarian-Universalist Women's Federation Clara Barton Sisters" (Unitarian-Universalist Women's Federation) 1989
Assorted Michigan-based women's groups, assorted records 1914, 1951

scopecontent.p: The Church Activities series (3.7 linear feet, one oversize box, and one oversize folder) is comprised of two subseries (Religious Education and Church Events).

The first subseries contains reports, financial records, policies and procedures, programs, and newsletters for the church's religious education program (known first as First U-U Sunday School and later as the Second Story Church). The subseries also contains the records of the Religious Education Committee, which consist predominantly of meeting minutes and reports. The bulk of the subseries is composed of curricular and reference materials, which include books and other publications intended primarily for children and adolescents on the topics of religious philosophy and values, spiritual and intellectual development, ethics, and the traditions of other religions. The subseries also contains a number of Christian, Universalist, and Unitarian periodicals and informational pamphlets on the topics of Unitarian-Universalist philosophy and history, religious liberalism, and political and social issues of importance to the church.

scopecontent.p: The second subseries is predominantly comprised of photographs of church events, which include conventions, fundraisers, trips, cultural and artistic programs, holidays, and social events. The subseries also includes two scrapbooks, which contain newspaper clippings, programs, and photographs of assorted church activities. The subseries also contains a small subset of materials pertaining to the church's political and social engagement, which includes such issues as racial and gender equality and opposition to war.

scopecontent.p: The Newsletters and Orders of Service series (5.3 linear feet) consists of church newsletters and orders of service (weekly worship programs), all of which are organized by year. The series contains newsletters from the years 1882-1903, 1926-1936, 1941-1943, 1954-1956, and 1958-2010, and orders of service from the years 1898-1916, 1932-1958, and 1969-2010.
